metadata.title: Modulating <ce:italic>e<ce:inf loc=post>g</ce:inf></ce:italic> orbitals through ligand engineering to boost the electrocatalytic activity of NiSe for advanced lithium-sulfur batteries

Modulating eg orbitals through ligand engineering to boost the electrocatalytic activity of NiSe for advanced lithium-sulfur batteries Tianran Yan a b Jie Feng a b Pan Zeng a Gang Zhao a Lei Wang a Cheng Yuan a Chen Cheng a Youyong Li a b Liang Zhang a c ⁎ a Institute of Functional Nano & Soft Materials (FUNSOM), Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, Jiangsu, China Institute of Functional Nano & Soft Materials (FUNSOM) Soochow University Suzhou 215123 Jiangsu China Institute of Functional Nano & Soft Materials (FUNSOM), Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, Jiangsu, China b Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Carbon-Based Functional Materials & Devices, Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, Jiangsu, China Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Carbon-Based Functional Materials & Devices Soochow University Suzhou 215123 Jiangsu China Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Carbon-Based Functional Materials & Devices, Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, Jiangsu, China c Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Negative Carbon Technologies, Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, Jiangsu, China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Negative Carbon Technologies Soochow University Suzhou 215123 Jiangsu China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Negative Carbon Technologies, Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, Jiangsu, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract An eg orbital modulation strategy has been proposed to boost the catalytic activity of NiSe toward lithium polysulfides redox conversion through ligand engineering. Accelerating the sluggish redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) by electrocatalysis is essential to achieve high performance lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. However, the issue of insufficient catalytic activity remains to be addressed. Herein, a strategy of modulating eg orbitals through ligand engineering has been proposed to boost the catalytic activity of NiSe for rapid LiPSs redox conversion. The X-ray spectroscopic measurements and theoretical calculations reveal that partial substitution of Se with N disrupts the octahedral coordination of Ni atoms in NiSe, leading to the reduced degeneracy and upward shift of eg orbitals of Ni 3d states. As a consequence, the bonding strength of N-substituted NiSe (N-NiSe) with LiPSs is enhanced, which facilitates the interfacial charge transfer kinetics and accelerates the LiPSs redox kinetics. Therefore, the Li-S batteries assembled with N-NiSe present a high capacity of 682.6 mAh g−1 at a high rate of 5 C and a high areal capacity of 6.5 mAh cm−2 at a high sulfur loading of 6 mg cm−2. This work provides a promising strategy to develop efficient transition-metal based electrocatalysts for Li-S batteries through eg orbital modulation. Keywords Li-S batteries eg orbitals modulation Ligand engineering Shuttle effect Redox kinetics 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have attracted growing attention due to their high theoretical specific capacity, low cost, and environmental benignity [1–3]. Nevertheless, the redox conversion of sulfur cathode involves multiple lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) intermediates with notorious shuttle effect and sluggish reaction kinetics, which plagues Li-S batteries with low energy density and poor cycle life [4–7]. During the past several years, appropriate catalytic centers have been introduced into Li-S batteries to improve the sulfur utilization and LiPSs reaction kinetics, leading to greatly enhanced specific capacity (>1100 mAh g−1) and extended cycle life (>500 cycles) [8–11]. Notably, these accomplishments were mostly achieved with low sulfur loading (<4 mg cm−2) and high electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio (>15 μL mg−1), which are far below the commercialization standard of Li-S batteries [12–14]. Furthermore, the exploration and development of efficient electrocatalysts for LiPSs conversion has been largely dependent on iterative trials, and more underlying mechanistic insights are therefore imperatively required to provide targeted guidance for further design and optimization of electrocatalysts for Li-S batteries [15–19]. For the typical Li-S electrochemistry, the efficient conversion of LiPSs normally requires a balanced adsorption-diffusion-conversion process [20,21]. Therefore, the ideal electrocatalysts should possess both superior adsorption strength and catalytic activity toward LiPSs, which are indispensable for promoting both sulfur utilization and battery cycle life, especially under high sulfur loading condition [15,22,23]. Given this, transition metal selenides (TMSes) have been regarded as promising candidates because of their combined half-metallic and polarization properties, which allow them to effectively anchor and catalytically convert LiPSs [24–26]. For example, CoSe2 nanodots were utilized to functionalize the separators to improve the kinetic behavior of LiPSs redox and regulate the homogeneous nucleation of Li2S [27]. Similarly, Xiong et al. synthesized few-layered MoSe2 nanosheets decorated graphene hybrids as sulfur host materials, which strongly immobilized the soluble LiPSs and promoted the LiPSs conversion [28]. However, the purely morphological and structural designs are not sufficient to fundamentally improve the catalytic activity of TMSes. According to the molecular orbital theory, the d orbitals of transition metals (TMs) play an essential role in catalytic processes, which hybridize with the p orbitals of adsorbed intermediates [29]. More specifically, for TMSes, the d orbitals of octahedrally coordinated TMs split into eg and t 2 g orbitals, which correspond to the dz 2 , dx 2 -y 2 and dxy, dyz, dxz orbitals, respectively [30,31]. For Li-S batteries, the adsorbed intermediates mainly include LiPSs, whose hybridization states are dominated by the p orbitals of sulfur. Based on the orbital energy diagrams, the eg orbitals of TMs and p orbitals of LiPSs form strong σ bonds, while the t 2 g orbitals remain nonbonded [29]. Therefore, according to the d-band theory, the catalytic activity of TMSes can be regulated through the adsorption strength toward LiPSs [32], while the adsorption strength can be controlled by tuning the energy level of eg orbitals [33]. However, how to effectively modulate the eg orbitals to further enhance the catalytic activity of TMSes toward LiPSs conversion has been rarely reported, which is critical to guide the design of efficient electrocatalysts for advanced Li-S batteries. Herein, we propose a strategy of modulating the eg orbitals through ligand engineering by partially substituting Se with N to optimize the d-band center of NiSe, which leads to improved catalytic activity toward LiPSs conversion. The X-ray spectroscopic and theoretical investigations demonstrate that the introduction of N atoms disrupts the octahedral structure of NiSe with the formation of shortened Ni-N bonds, leading to the upward shift of the eg orbitals of Ni with reduced degeneracy. As a consequence, the binding interaction of N-substituted NiSe (N-NiSe) with LiPSs is enhanced, thereby facilitating the interfacial charge transfer kinetics and lowering the LiPSs conversion barrier. Because of these advantages, the Li-S batteries assembled with N-NiSe demonstrate superior cycling performance and energy density under practical test conditions of high current density, high sulfur loading, and low E/S ratio. The present study provides a promising approach to designing efficient electrocatalysts by manipulating the eg orbitals for advanced Li-S batteries. 2 Results and discussion The N-NiSe nanoparticles were synthesized through a facile one-step hydrothermal method, as schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). The details of the synthesis process are provided in the Supporting Information. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images reveal the uniform distribution of N-NiSe nanoparticles with an average size of ∼20 nm (Fig. 1b, c and Fig. S1), as similar to that of NiSe (Fig. S2a). The scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image and corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDXS) elemental mapping manifest the successful incorporation of N into NiSe with a homogeneous distribution (Fig. 1d–g). Moreover, the lattice spacing of 0.261 nm from the high-resolution TEM image of N-NiSe (Fig. 1h) is ascribed to the (101) plane, which is slightly smaller than that of NiSe (0.274 nm, Fig. S2b). The contraction of lattice spacing should be related to the smaller radius of N compared with the substituted Se [34]. The crystal structure of N-NiSe was further unveiled by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As illustrated in Fig. S3, all the diffraction peaks can be indexed to a pure hexagonal NiSe phase (JCPDS No. 01-075-0610), indicating that the N substitution does not alter the hexagonal crystal structure of NiSe. Notably, the (101) diffraction peak of N-NiSe slightly shifts to a higher angle compared to that of NiSe, indicating the lattice contraction caused by the N substitution, which is consistent with the TEM result. In addition, the Rietveld refinement results (Fig. 1i and Table S1) show that the N atoms mainly occupy the 2c Wyckoff sites, suggesting the partial substitution of Se by N in N-NiSe. In order to further investigate the effect of N ligand engineering on the electronic structure and local coordination environment of Ni atoms in N-NiSe, Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) were conducted. For the Ni K-edge XANES spectra, the absorption energy of N-NiSe is higher than that of NiSe, indicating that the Ni atoms in N-NiSe are more positively charged because of the higher electronegativity of N than that of Se (Fig. 2 a). In addition, the Fourier-transformed k 3-weighted EXAFS (FT-EXAFS) spectrum of NiSe exhibits a single peak located at 2.50 Å (Fig. 2b), which corresponds to the Ni-Se bond coordination. Notably, this peak becomes slightly broader and negatively shifted for N-NiSe, implying the change of Ni coordination environment after N substitution. The quantitative structural parameters of Ni atoms in N-NiSe were obtained by least-square EXAFS fitting (Fig. 2c, Fig. S4a–c and Table S2). The results reveal that the Ni-Se coordination number decreases from 6 for NiSe to 4.63 for N-NiSe. Additional Ni-N bond coordination with a coordination number of 1.75 is also resolved for N-NiSe. Meanwhile, the Ni-Ni coordination number is almost constant before and after N substitution, suggesting that the N atoms mainly replace the Se atoms in NiSe, which is consistent with the Rietveled refinement results. Moreover, the bond length of Ni-N bond coordination (2.12 Å) is considerably shorter than that of Ni-Se bond coordination (2.47 Å), which induces the lattice shrinkage and distorted symmetry of Ni octahedral coordination [35]. Since the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries largely depends on the adsorption capability of the electrocatalysts toward LiPSs [20], adsorption experiments and UV–vis measurements were conducted by adding NiSe and N-NiSe into Li2S6 solution to elucidate the effect of N substitution on the LiPSs entrapment [36]. The color of Li2S6 solution with N-NiSe becomes colorless after standing for 6 h while the color of the solution with NiSe remains yellowish (Fig. S5). In addition, the solution with N-NiSe also exhibits the largest reduction of Li2S6 peak intensity in the UV–vis spectra (Fig. 3 a), suggesting that N substitution can greatly enhance the adsorption ability of N-NiSe toward LiPSs [37]. Such a strengthened absorption ability could facilitate the charge transfer at the N-NiSe/Li2S6 interface and thus boost the catalytic activity for LiPSs redox reaction. To gain an in-depth understanding of the chemical interaction between LiPSs and N-NiSe, Ni and Se K-edge XANES and EXAFS spectra were measured. After interacting with Li2S6, the white-line intensity of Ni K-edge XANES spectrum of N-NiSe is enhanced (Fig. 3b), while the Se K-edge absorption edge remains largely unchanged (Fig. S5), indicating that the Ni atoms in N-NiSe are the main active sites to form strong chemical bonds with LiPSs. This scenario is further corroborated by the corresponding FT-EXAFS spectra. The peak of Ni-Se/N bond coordination in the Ni K-edge FT-EXAFS spectrum gets broadened and negatively shifted after interacting with LiPSs as a consequence of the formation of additional Ni-S bond coordination (Fig. 3c), while no appreciable change is observed for the peak of Se-Ni bond coordination in the Se K-edge FT-EXAFS spectrum (Fig. 3d). The strong LiPSs adsorption of N-NiSe is further examined by the wavelet transform (WT) contour plot to highlight the contribution of multiple scattering paths in both k and R spaces [38]. As shown in Fig. 3(e), compared to NiSe, N-NiSe shows a stronger signal at 5 Å−1 due to the formation of Ni-N bond coordination as discussed above. After interacting with Li2S6, an additional wider signal emerges at 10 Å−1, which should be ascribed to the coordination contribution with heavier sulfur elements as a consequence of the formation of Ni-S bond coordination [39]. Having clarified the adsorption mechanism of N-NiSe toward LiPSs, the catalytic activity of N-NiSe for LiPSs redox conversion was further evaluated. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements of symmetric cells assembled with NiSe and N-NiSe identical electrodes were performed. As demonstrated in Fig. 3(f), N-NiSe exhibits strong redox peaks with higher current density and smaller electrochemical polarization, suggesting a faster and more efficient LiPSs conversion [40]. The enhanced LiPSs conversion kinetics was also consolidated by the Li2S nucleation experiment [41]. N-NiSe delivers both earlier precipitation response and higher precipitation capacity compared with NiSe (Fig. 3g and h), clearly verifying the improved electrocatalytic activity of N-NiSe toward LiPSs conversion. In addition, a uniform and compact Li2S layer is obtained on the N-NiSe surface, while obvious Li2S aggregation occurs on the NiSe surface, which should be related to the different affinity and catalytic activity of NiSe and N-NiSe toward LiPSs as discussed above (Fig. S7). Because of the above-mentioned advantages of N-NiSe, the electrochemical performances of Li-S batteries with N-NiSe modified separators were evaluated. The coin cells were assembled with lithium metal as anode and sulfur/carbon nanotubes as cathode with a sulfur content of 75 wt% (Fig. S8). Fig. 4 (a) presents the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) profiles of Li-S batteries with different modified separators. It is apparent that the cell with N-NiSe modified separator delivers a smaller charge transfer resistance (12.48 Ω) compared to the cell with NiSe modified cell (17.59 Ω). This observation indicates that the introduction of N enables the faster electron transfer kinetics at the LiPSs/N-NiSe interface, which should be advantageous for enhancing the LiPSs redox kinetics [42]. Another factor that influences the redox kinetics of LiPSs is the Li+ diffusion rate. Hence, CV measurements at different scan rates from 0.1 to 0.3 mV s−1 were conducted to investigate the Li+ diffusion kinetics (Fig. 4b and Fig. S9a). The two cathodic peaks located at ∼2.25 V (peak C1) and ∼2.0 V (peak C2) are assigned to the conversion of S8 to long-chain LiPSs and the subsequent reduction to insoluble Li2S, respectively, while the anodic peak located at ∼2.3 V (peak A1) corresponds to the conversion of Li2S to S8 [43]. The currents of both cathodic and anionic peaks demonstrate a linear relationship with the square root of the scanning rate, and therefore, the Li+ diffusion coefficient (D Li +) was also calculated using the CV results based on the Randles-Sevcik equation, as shown in Fig. S9(b–d) [44,45]. It is apparent that the cell with N-NiSe modified separator demonstrates a higher D Li + for all the redox peaks (Table S3), implying the smaller Li+ diffusion barrier on the N-NiSe surface. Benefitting from the prompted electron and Li+ transfer kinetics, the complicated solid–liquid-solid multiphase sulfur conversions were thus accelerated. The CV curves (Fig. 4c) show that the intensities of both cathodic and anionic peaks of the cell with N-NiSe are higher than that with NiSe accompanied by a smaller electrochemical polarization, suggesting that the precipitation and decomposition of Li2S are both promoted by N-NiSe. Additionally, smaller Tafel slopes for the S8 reduction process as well as the Li2S oxidation process are observed for N-NiSe (Fig. S10a–c) [46]. Moreover, the activation energy (E a) calculated from the Tafel plots demonstrates that N-NiSe enables the reduced E a value for the reduction of S8 to LiPSs (ΔE a1 = 34.4 KJ mol−1) and then to Li2S (ΔE a2 = 63.5 KJ mol−1) as well as the oxidation of Li2S to S8 (ΔE a3 = 112 KJ mol−1) (Fig. S11), indicating that the conversions between sulfur species are more thermodynamically favorable on the N-NiSe surface [47,48]. Overall, these results unambiguously demonstrate the facilitated interfacial charge transfer and boosted sulfur redox kinetics by N-NiSe, which could lead to the enhanced electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. To demonstrate this, the electrochemical performances of Li-S batteries with N-NiSe modified separators were examined. Fig. 4(d) shows the galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles at 0.1 C (1 C = 1675 mAh g−1). Two typical discharge plateaus are observed at around 2.3 V and 2.1 V, which are consistent with a two-step reaction mechanism. In addition, a plateau occurs at around 1.8 V, which is due to the inadequate wetting of the host or active material by the electrolyte. The battery with N-NiSe modified separator achieves a higher specific capacity of 1433.5 mAh g−1 compared with the batteries with NiSe modified and pristine separators, suggesting the remarkably enhanced sulfur utilization. In addition, the smaller voltage gap between the charge and discharge profiles of the battery with N-NiSe modified separator indicates a smaller polarization potential, which is generally considered to be more favorable for the conversion of LiPSs [49]. In addition, the battery with N-NiSe modified separator demonstrates the best cyclability with a high discharge capacity of 1021.1 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 4e). These results confirm that N-NiSe can effectively inhibit the LiPSs shuttle effect and improve sulfur utilization by accelerating conversion kinetics. The rate performance of different modified separators was further performed to evaluate the LiPSs redox kinetics (Fig. 4f and Fig. S12). With increasing the current density, the polarization potential also increases accompanied by a decrease in the discharge specific capacity. However, even at a high current density of 5 C, the battery with N-NiSe modified separator still delivers a high reversible capacity of 682.6 mAh g−1. In contrast, due to the inferior LiPSs retention and catalysis, a reversible capacity of only 424.6 mAh g−1 is achieved for the battery with NiSe modified separator. Long-term cycling performance of N-NiSe modified separator was also performed at a high current density of 1 C (Fig. 4g). A discharge capacity of 505.5 mAh g−1 is still maintained after 1000 cycles, which corresponds to a low capacity decay of 0.047% per cycle, indicating the persistence of N-NiSe for the chemisorption and transformation of LiPSs over extended cycles. To demonstrate the practical application of N-NiSe, the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries under high sulfur loading and low E/S ratio conditions was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 4(h), a high areal capacity of 6.5 mAh cm−2 is achieved with a high sulfur loading of 6 mg cm−2, which is still retained to 4.4 mAh cm−2 after 100 cycles with a nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency. This indicates that even at high LiPSs concentrations, N-NiSe can still effectively confine them to the cathode region to avoid the loss of active material, which is mainly ascribed to its enhanced adsorption capacity toward LiPSs. Moreover, because of the enhanced LiPSs redox kinetics by N-NiSe, high rate performance is also realized at a high sulfur loading of 5.0 mg cm−2 with areal capacities of 4.3, 3.9, 3.4, 2.6, and 2.0 mAh cm−2 at 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1 C, respectively (Fig. S13a). With decreasing the E/S ratio to 8 μL mg−1, the battery still delivers a high areal capacity of 3.4 mAh cm−2 after 60 cycles (Fig. S13b). The excellent cycle performance with a high sulfur loading and low E/S ratio should be attributed to the high catalytic activity of N-NiSe precipitated with reactive Li2S, which guarantees the fast electron/Li+ diffusion as well as accelerated LiPSs conversion at the electrolyte/N-NiSe interfaces. A comprehensive performance comparison with different separators employed in Li-S batteries is listed in Table S4. The electrochemical performance achieved by N-NiSe is comparable to or even better than the other materials, manifesting the high promise of N-NiSe for the practical application of Li-S batteries. The above experimental results clearly demonstrate that the ligand engineering by partially substituting Se in NiSe with N could significantly promote the chemical interaction with LiPSs and boost the LiPSs redox kinetics, thus enhancing the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. In addition, the adsorption experiments reveal that N-NiSe interacts with LiPSs mainly through the Ni sites. According to previous reports, the d-p orbital hybridization between the Ni atoms of N-NiSe and LiPSs largely dominates the adsorption strength, which could greatly influence the catalytic ability of LiPSs [29]. Therefore, the projected density of state (PDOS) of Ni 3d states in NiSe and N-NiSe was calculated using density functional theory (DFT). According to the orbital energy diagrams, the eg (namely dx 2 -y 2 and dz 2) orbitals of Ni atoms and p orbitals of LiPSs form strong σ bonds, while the t 2 g (namely dxy, dxz, and dyz ) orbitals are nonbonded [31,50]. Therefore, we will mainly focus on the eg orbitals in the following discussion to demonstrate the influence of N ligand engineering effect. For the octahedrally coordinated Ni atoms in NiSe (Fig. S14a and c), the eg orbitals are composed of the twofold degenerate dx 2 -y 2 and dz 2 orbitals (Fig. 5 a and b). In contrast, the formation of shortened Ni-N bonds after partially substituting Se with N distorts the octahedral symmetry of Ni atoms in N-NiSe (Fig. S14b and d), which leads to the reduced degeneracy of eg orbitals with the upward shift of the dz 2 and dx 2 -y 2 orbitals by 0.09 and 0.06 eV, respectively. As a result, the d-band center of Ni in N-NiSe is shifted closer to the Fermi level compared to that of NiSe. According to the d-band center theory [51,52], when LiPSs are adsorbed on the N-NiSe surface, the antibonding orbitals caused by the coupling of S 3p and Ni 3d states can be elevated closer or above the Fermi level with the upward shift of the d-band center. Therefore, the bonding strength between LiPSs and N-NiSe is largely enhanced through the N substitution, as corroborated by the experimental results. In addition, the strong binding interaction between LiPSs and N-NiSe also facilitates the interfacial charge transfer and thus promotes the redox conversion of LiPSs, ensuring an efficient adsorption-diffusion-conversion process of LiPSs on N-NiSe surface to achieve improved electrochemical performance (Fig. 5c). Note that the eg orbital modulation strategy can also be extended to other metal based electrocatalysts if the metal ions are located at the octahedral sites. 3 Conclusions In summary, we have proposed an eg orbital modulation strategy to boost the catalytic activity of NiSe toward LiPSs redox conversion through ligand engineering. By partially substituting Se with N, the octahedral coordination environment of Ni atoms in NiSe is disrupted, which results in the reduced degeneracy of eg orbitals and entails the upward shift of the corresponding band center. As a consequence, the adsorption strength of N-NiSe toward LiPSs is largely enhanced, which thereby improves the N-NiSe/LiPSs interfacial charge transfer kinetics and enhances the LiPSs redox kinetics. Benefitting from this eg orbital modulation strategy, the Li-S batteries assembled with N-NiSe exhibit a high rate performance (682.6 mAh g−1 at 5 C) and low capacity decay rate (0.047% per cycle over 1000 cycles at 1 C). More encouragingly, stable cycling performance under a high sulfur load of 6 mg cm−2 and a low E/S ratio of 8 µL mg−1 is realized by N-NiSe. Our present work provides a new guideline for developing high-performance electrocatalysts for practical Li-S batteries through modulating the eg orbitals with ligand engineering. coredata.dc:description: Accelerating the sluggish redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) by electrocatalysis is essential to achieve high performance lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. However, the issue of insufficient catalytic activity remains to be addressed. Herein, a strategy of modulating eg orbitals through ligand engineering has been proposed to boost the catalytic activity of NiSe for rapid LiPSs redox conversion. The X-ray spectroscopic measurements and theoretical calculations reveal that partial substitution of Se with N disrupts the octahedral coordination of Ni atoms in NiSe, leading to the reduced degeneracy and upward shift of eg orbitals of Ni 3d states. As a consequence, the bonding strength of N-substituted NiSe (N-NiSe) with LiPSs is enhanced, which facilitates the interfacial charge transfer kinetics and accelerates the LiPSs redox kinetics. Therefore, the Li-S batteries assembled with N-NiSe present a high capacity of 682.6 mAh g−1 at a high rate of 5 C and a high areal capacity of 6.5 mAh cm−2 at a high sulfur loading of 6 mg cm−2. This work provides a promising strategy to develop efficient transition-metal based electrocatalysts for Li-S batteries through eg orbital modulation.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by ELSEVIER B.V. and Science Press.
coredata.dc:title: Modulating eg orbitals through ligand engineering to boost the electrocatalytic activity of NiSe for advanced lithium-sulfur batteries
